tn.text: to be comfortable and happy, without the desire to move or change.
The wood from cedar trees was considered the best wood for construction.

tn.ref: do what is in your heart
tn.text: David is referred to by the part of the body associated with emotions. AT: "do what you would like to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Being in agreement with God is like working together with him because God will help you succeed. AT: "God agrees with what you want to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"God spoke his word" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
AT: "that I brought the Israelites to the promised land from the land of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Both the words "tent" and "tabernacle" describe the same thing and emphasize that he had lived in a place that was not a permanent building. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: Why have you not built me a house of cedar?
tn.text: AT: "You should have built me a house with expensive wood." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: I took you from the pasture
tn.text: David's job as a shepherd is referred to by the place he watched his sheep. AT: "I took you from your job as a shepherd" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
See how you translated this word in [[:en:bible:notes:1ch:04:39|4:40]].
God continues to speak the message Nathan is supposed to give to David.
God refers to putting Israel in the promised land like a plant he has put in the ground. AT: "I will settle them there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: from the days that I commanded
tn.text: A time period of many generations is referred to by days. AT: "when I commanded" or "from the generations that I commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: to be over my people Israel
tn.text: To be in authority is referred to as being over someone. AT: "to command my people Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: all your enemies ... I tell you
tn.text: The words "your" and "you" refer to David.
to make a person or animal unable to attack.
Yahweh refers to giving David many descendants to rule over Israel as building him a house. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Life is referred to as a certain number of days. AT: "when you die" (See: [[
en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This phrase refers to death as a place where David's ancestors are because they are already dead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I will raise up your descendant
tn.text: To put someone in leadership is referred to as raising them higher. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The right to rule as king is described by the place where a king sits. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
A king's right to rule is referred to by the place a king sits. AT: "and his right to rule" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"told him"
"David said"

tn.ref: Who am I, Yahweh God, and what is my family, that you have brought me to this point?
tn.text: David asks this question to express his gratitude that God has chosen to bless him even though he does not deserve it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Something that is not important is described as being small. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Yahweh's sight is used to refer to his understanding. AT: "to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: What more can I, David, say to you?
tn.text: David uses this question to express that he cannot fully express his thankfulness to God. AT: "If I could say more to express my gratitude then I would but I do not know what else to say. " (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
David refers to himself as Yahweh's servant.

tn.ref: You have honored your servant. You have given your servant special recognition
tn.text: Both of these phrases have the same meaning. If your language only has one way to express "honor" and "recognition" then this can be translated as one phrase. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
AT: "my benefit"
AT: "rescued from slavery in Egypt. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The words "great" and "awesome" mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of greatness. AT: "very awesome deeds." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
AT: "continue forever"
To have children and develop a large family is described as building a house. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
AT: "become courageous enough"

tn.ref: blessed it, and it will be blessed forever
tn.text: Means the same thing, repeated here for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
